definitions.definition: the sound produced in a person's larynx and uttered through the mouth, as speech or song.
an agency by which a particular point of view is expressed or represented.
examples: once the proud voice of middle-class conservatism, the paper had fallen on hard times

definitions.definition: the right to express an opinion.
examples: the new electoral system gives minority parties a voice
synonyms: seat at the table "citizens must have a voice in this"

definitions.definition: a particular opinion or attitude expressed.
synonyms: will; Morevox populi; informalvox pop "we speak with one voice"

definitions.definition: the ability to speak or sing.
synonyms: power of speech "she lost her voice"

definitions.definition: the supposed utterance of a guiding spirit, typically giving instructions or advice.
the distinctive tone or style of a literary work or author.
examples: she had strained and falsified her literary voice

definitions.definition: the range of pitch or type of tone with which a person sings, such as soprano or tenor.
a vocal part in a composition.
a constituent part in a fugue.
each of the notes or sounds able to be produced simultaneously by a musical instrument (especially an electronic one) or a computer.
(in an electronic musical instrument) each of a number of preset or programmable tones.
sound uttered with resonance of the vocal cords (used in the pronunciation of vowels and certain consonants).
a form or set of forms of a verb showing the relation of the subject to the action.

examples: get teachers to voice their opinions on important subjects
synonyms: speak; informalcome out with "they voiced their opposition"

definitions.definition: utter (a speech sound) with resonance of the vocal cords (e.g., b, d, g, v, z ).
regulate the tone quality of (organ pipes).
